## Barcelona's Sagrada Familia basilica becomes world's tallest church - <small>`bbc`</small>

- [source](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/ce9dr45g49yo)
- _Published: 2025-10-31 02:40:47.641+00:00_
- **Science & Technology**
- <small>tags: `architecture, Barcelona, antoni-gaudí, religious-structure, world-record, construction, cultural-heritage, historical-challenges`</small>

### Summary

The Sagrada Família basilica in Barcelona has officially become the world's tallest church, surpassing the Ulm Minster in Germany, after the placement of the first part of a cross on its central tower. Designed by Antoni Gaudí and begun in 1882, the church has been under construction for over 140 years, facing major setbacks including destruction during the Spanish Civil War and a pause during the Covid-19 pandemic. The central Tower of Jesus Christ is expected to reach 172 meters by 2026, marking the centenary of Gaudí’s death, and will be completed through continued work on structural elements and decorative features. The project is sustained by donations from tourists and private contributors via the Sagrada Família Foundation, which manages the site and its long-term development.

### Key Takeaways
  - The Sagrada Família in Barcelona has officially become the tallest church in the world, surpassing the Ulm Minster in Germany, which held the title since 1890.
  - The basilica, designed by Antoni Gaudí and begun in 1882, has been under construction for over 140 years, with only one of Gaudí's 18 towers completed at the time of his death in 1926.
  - The central tower is set to reach 172 meters in height with the addition of the full cross structure over the next few months.
  - The construction has faced major setbacks, including destruction during the Spanish Civil War and a pause during the Covid-19 pandemic due to reduced tourism and funding.
  - The Sagrada Família Foundation continues to fund and manage the project through donations from tourists, visitors, and private contributors.
  - A key milestone is the completion of the Tower of Jesus Christ in 2026, coinciding with the centenary of Antoni Gaudí's death.
  - The foundation will hold commemorative events to honor Gaudí, who is buried in the church's crypt.

### Named Entities
- **Sagrada Família**
    - A basilica in Barcelona, Spain, designed by Antoni Gaudí.
    - The Sagrada Família is central to the article as the primary subject — it has officially become the world’s tallest church, marking a significant achievement in architectural history.
- **Antoni Gaudí**
    - The renowned Catalan architect who designed the Sagrada Família.
    - Gaudí is central to the basilica’s history and design; his vision and death in 1926 were pivotal in shaping the project’s long-term development and construction challenges.
- **Ulm Minster**
    - A church in Ulm, Germany, previously the tallest church in the world.
    - It held the record for the tallest church since 1890, making its recent surpassed status a key point in the article's narrative.
- **Central Tower of Jesus Christ**
    - The central spire of the Sagrada Família, currently being completed with the addition of a cross.
    - This tower is the focal point of the construction progress, with its completion scheduled for 2026 and currently standing at 162.91 meters.
- **Sagrada Família Foundation**
    - The organization managing and funding the construction of the basilica.
    - The foundation oversees ongoing construction and fundraising, playing a crucial role in sustaining the project through challenges like the pandemic and wartime destruction.
- **Spanish Civil War**
    - A conflict in Spain (1936–1939) during which the crypt of the Sagrada Família was destroyed.
    - The war caused significant damage to original Gaudí designs and construction models, impacting the continuity and planning of the basilica’s development.
- **Covid-19 pandemic**
    - A global health crisis that disrupted construction timelines and funding for the basilica.
    - The pandemic led to a halt in construction due to reduced tourism and financial support, highlighting the vulnerability of long-term architectural projects to external events.
- **Xavier Martínez**
    - General Director of the Sagrada Família Foundation.
    - He provided official statements about the completion timeline, linking the 2026 completion to the centenary of Gaudí's death.

### Important Dates
  - **1882-01-01**
    - The first stone of the Sagrada Família was laid in 1882, marking the official start of construction.
  - **1926-06-10**
    - Antoni Gaudí died in 1926, leaving only one of the 18 towers completed and significantly impacting the project's direction.
  - **2026-06-10**
    - The completion of the central Tower of Jesus Christ is scheduled for 2026, marking the centenary of Gaudí's death and a key milestone in the basilica's history.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _2024-01-01_ to _2025-10-31_**
    - The recent completion of the first part of the cross on the central tower places the Sagrada Família at 162.91 meters, officially surpassing the Ulm Minster as the tallest church in the world.
  - **From _2025-01-01_ to _2026-06-10_**
    - Construction of the central Tower of Jesus Christ is expected to continue through 2026, culminating in the full completion of the tower at 172 meters.

## The Witcher season 4: Can new cast escape shadow of Henry Cavill? - <small>`bbc`</small>

- [source](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cn8x3v1ng25o)
- _Published: 2025-10-30 15:42:56.009+00:00_
- **Science & Technology**
- <small>tags: `The Witcher, casting change, Henry Cavill, Liam Hemsworth, Geralt of Rivia, fantasy television, fan reactions, netflix, warhammer 40k, review, creative decision`</small>

### Summary

The Witcher season 4 has been released with a major casting change: Liam Hemsworth replaces Henry Cavill as Geralt of Rivia. Cavill, who had portrayed the character since the beginning, announced in October 2022 that he was passing the torch, citing Hemsworth as a 'fantastic' actor. While fans were divided—some threatening boycotts and others criticizing Hemsworth's performance—the show's cast and crew have worked to manage the transition. Critics offer mixed reviews, with Variety calling it an 'upgrade' and The Guardian offering a sharp critique. Professional reviewers like Sabrina Barr and Dawson Roberts acknowledge the shift is difficult but note that the narrative remains engaging and the new performance is solid. Laurence Fishburne is praised as a standout new addition. Cavill, meanwhile, has moved into a role in Amazon’s Warhammer 40,000 series, signaling a new chapter in his career. This change underscores the evolving nature of long-running franchises and the challenges and risks of altering a beloved lead character.

### Key Takeaways
  - Henry Cavill, the former lead actor, has been replaced by Liam Hemsworth as Geralt of Rivia in the latest season of The Witcher.
  - The casting change was announced in October 2022, with Cavill describing Hemsworth as a 'fantastic' actor and stating he was passing the torch.
  - Fans were divided, with some threatening to boycott the series, and Hemsworth acknowledged it is a 'daunting' role to follow.
  - Early reviews are mixed: Variety called it an 'upgrade', while the Guardian described Hemsworth as 'as charismatic as a bollard in a wig'.
  - Professional reviewers like Sabrina Barr and Dawson Roberts acknowledge the transition is difficult but agree it works due to strong support from the cast and crew.
  - Laurence Fishburne joins the cast as vampire Regis and is praised by reviewers as an unsung hero of the season.
  - There is no official explanation for Cavill's departure, though creative differences and a commitment to source material are cited as possible reasons.
  - Cavill has since moved into a role as a producer and star in Amazon's Warhammer 40,000 series, a dream role for him.

### Named Entities
- **Henry Cavill**
    - Former lead actor in The Witcher
    - He was the original portrayal of Geralt of Rivia and his departure marks a significant shift in the series' identity and fan reception.
- **Liam Hemsworth**
    - New lead actor in The Witcher season 4
    - He has taken over the role of Geralt of Rivia, replacing Henry Cavill, and is now central to the narrative and audience perception of the season.
- **The Witcher**
    - Fantasy television series based on novels and video games
    - It is the central platform for the casting change and creative decision, representing a major shift in the franchise's evolution and public reception.
- **Geralt of Rivia**
    - Main character of The Witcher series
    - The central character whose portrayal has changed from Henry Cavill to Liam Hemsworth, affecting continuity, fan expectations, and narrative tone.
- **Laurence Fishburne**
    - New cast member in The Witcher season 4
    - He joins as vampire Regis, praised by critics as a standout performance and an unsung hero of the season.
- **Warhammer 40,000**
    - Sci-fi universe and upcoming Amazon series
    - Henry Cavill is now starring in and producing a series based on this universe, indicating a shift in his career post-The Witcher.
- **Variety**
    - US magazine
    - Provided a positive review of the new season, calling it an 'upgrade', influencing public perception of the casting change.
- **The Guardian**
    - UK newspaper
    - Offered a critical review of Liam Hemsworth's performance, describing it as 'as charismatic as a bollard in a wig', contributing to mixed fan reactions.
- **BBC Newsbeat**
    - News program
    - Conducted interviews with professional reviewers to assess the quality and reception of the new season.
- **Sabrina Barr**
    - TV Editor at Metro
    - Provided a three-and-a-half star review and insights into fan reactions and the challenges of casting a new main actor.
- **Dawson Roberts**
    - Content creator and reviewer (DawsOnScreen)
    - Offered a balanced perspective, acknowledging the difficulty of the transition but affirming the show's excitement and quality.

### Important Dates
  - **2022-10-01**
    - Henry Cavill announced he was passing the torch to Liam Hemsworth in October 2022, signaling a major shift in the casting of The Witcher season 4.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _2022-10-01_ to _2025-10-30_**
    - The period from 2022 to 2025 covers the announcement of the casting change, the production of Season 4, and its release, marking a pivotal creative transition in the series' history.

## Nvidia expands global AI rollout with bumper South Korea deals - <small>`bbc`</small>

- [source](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cyv862r7l2ro)
- _Published: 2025-10-31 11:24:46.428+00:00_
- **Science & Technology**
- <small>tags: `Artificial Intelligence, Technology, South Korea, US-China Trade War, Nvidia, AI Chips, Digital Twins, Sovereign AI, Semiconductors, Geopolitical Technology, Global Manufacturing, Innovation`</small>

### Summary

Nvidia has signed a major global AI expansion deal with South Korea, supplying over 260,000 of its advanced AI chips to the South Korean government and key companies including Samsung, LG, and Hyundai. These chips will power AI infrastructure in factories for producing semiconductors, robots, and autonomous vehicles, enabling the creation of 'digital twins' to optimize global manufacturing. The deal supports South Korea’s ambition to become a regional AI hub and build 'sovereign AI' infrastructure. The move comes amid ongoing geopolitical tensions from the US-China trade war, where China previously had 95% of Nvidia’s AI market but now has zero access due to US export controls. While Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang expresses hope for a return of chip sales to China, final decisions require US presidential approval. The announcement follows a surge in Nvidia’s valuation to $5 trillion and new global partnerships with US government agencies and major corporations like Nokia, Uber, and Stellantis, reinforcing confidence in AI-driven innovation and global economic integration.

### Key Takeaways
  - Nvidia has signed major deals with South Korea's government and key companies (Samsung, LG, Hyundai) to supply over 260,000 of its most advanced AI chips.
  - The deals are part of Nvidia's broader strategy to expand global AI infrastructure and integrate AI into manufacturing, robotics, and autonomous vehicles.
  - South Korea aims to become a regional AI hub, leveraging its energy access, land, and industrial capacity to develop 'sovereign AI' through its own computing infrastructure powered by Nvidia chips.
  - Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang emphasized that the AI chips will enable 'digital twins'—virtual replicas of factories—allowing global factories to be interconnected and optimized.
  - The South Korea deals occur amid ongoing tensions from the US-China trade war, where China once accounted for over 10% of Nvidia’s revenue but now has zero AI chip access due to export controls.
  - US President Donald Trump suggested that China and Nvidia will hold talks to resume chip exports, with the US acting as a 'referee', though final decisions require presidential approval.
  - Nvidia has expressed a desire to sell its Blackwell AI chips to China, though it remains subject to US export restrictions and presidential authorization.
  - Nvidia’s share price rose due to new global partnerships (with US Department of Energy, Nokia, Uber, Stellantis) and optimism around China market revival.
  - China has responded to US restrictions by developing domestic alternatives, such as Huawei and Alibaba’s AI chips, and has banned local firms from purchasing from Nvidia to promote domestic tech industries.
  - Nvidia is dependent on Asian supply chains, with TSMC manufacturing its advanced chips and Samsung producing components for its H20 chips for the Chinese market under export rules.

### Named Entities
- **Nvidia**
    - A US-based semiconductor and AI technology company, primarily known for designing AI chips such as the Blackwell series.
    - Nvidia is central to the article as the driving force behind AI infrastructure expansion, with major new deals in South Korea and ongoing efforts to re-enter the Chinese market.
- **Jensen Huang**
    - Chief Executive Officer of Nvidia, a key figure in shaping the company’s global AI strategy and public statements on international trade and technology policies.
    - Huang’s public statements about AI expansion, digital twins, and China market hopes provide the central narrative of the article’s strategic and geopolitical dimensions.
- **South Korea**
    - A global technology and manufacturing hub, home to major semiconductor and automotive industries, with ambitions to become a regional AI center.
    - South Korea is the primary recipient of Nvidia’s AI chip deals and is leveraging them to build sovereign AI infrastructure, signaling a major shift in regional technological leadership.
- **Samsung**
    - A South Korean multinational corporation, a key partner in the AI chip deployment and manufacturing of semiconductors and electronics.
    - Samsung is one of the companies receiving Nvidia’s AI chips for use in factories and is part of South Korea’s AI infrastructure expansion strategy.
- **LG**
    - A South Korean multinational corporation involved in electronics, manufacturing, and technology applications.
    - LG is among the companies receiving Nvidia’s AI chips for industrial and technological applications in factories and smart systems.
- **Hyundai**
    - A South Korean automotive giant that is integrating AI chips into vehicle development and autonomous driving technologies.
    - Hyundai is using Nvidia AI chips to advance its autonomous vehicle and smart manufacturing initiatives, aligning with South Korea’s AI ambitions.
- **TSMC**
    - A Taiwanese semiconductor manufacturing company, a key partner in producing Nvidia’s most advanced AI chips, including the Blackwell series.
    - TSMC is essential to Nvidia’s supply chain, manufacturing the high-end AI chips that are being deployed globally, including in South Korea and China.
- **China**
    - A global economic and technological power with a growing AI sector, currently restricted from accessing Nvidia’s most advanced chips due to US export controls.
    - China’s restricted access to Nvidia chips is a key geopolitical issue, with implications for AI development, military applications, and US-China tech competition.
- **United States**
    - A global superpower with significant influence over international technology trade, including export controls on AI chips to China.
    - The US government enforces export controls on Nvidia chips to China, shaping the global AI technology landscape and influencing Nvidia’s market access and strategic decisions.
- **Donald Trump**
    - Former US President, who reportedly suggested that China and Nvidia will hold trade talks on AI chip exports, with the US acting as a 'referee'.
    - Trump’s statement signals a potential shift in US-China tech relations, creating hope for renewed Nvidia chip exports to China and impacting global AI market dynamics.
- **Xi Jinping**
    - Chinese President, mentioned in the context of talks with Trump on AI chip exports to China.
    - Xi’s involvement in discussions with Trump underscores the political dimension of AI chip access and China’s desire to develop domestic alternatives.
- **Huawei**
    - A Chinese technology company that has developed AI chips to compete with Nvidia, particularly in response to export restrictions.
    - Huawei’s domestic chip initiatives reflect China’s response to being cut off from Nvidia, highlighting a strategic shift in global AI competition.
- **Alibaba**
    - A Chinese e-commerce and technology giant that has unveiled AI chips to rival Nvidia’s products in China.
    - Alibaba’s move signals a broader trend of Chinese companies developing indigenous AI technology to circumvent US restrictions and reduce dependency on Nvidia.
- **US Department of Energy**
    - A US government agency that has signed a partnership with Nvidia for AI-driven energy projects.
    - This partnership shows Nvidia’s efforts to expand AI applications beyond tech, into energy and infrastructure, reinforcing its global relevance.
- **Nokia**
    - A global telecommunications company partnering with Nvidia to integrate AI into network infrastructure.
    - The partnership illustrates Nvidia’s expansion into critical sectors beyond semiconductors, such as telecommunications and smart networks.
- **Uber**
    - A global transportation company partnering with Nvidia to apply AI in autonomous vehicles and logistics.
    - Uber’s collaboration shows how Nvidia’s AI chips are being used in real-world applications like self-driving cars and intelligent transportation systems.
- **Stellantis**
    - An Italian automotive conglomerate partnering with Nvidia to apply AI in vehicle manufacturing and autonomous systems.
    - This partnership underscores the global use of Nvidia AI chips in the automotive sector, especially in autonomous vehicle development.
- **Lee Jae-myung**
    - President of South Korea, who has prioritized AI investment in response to US tariffs.
    - Lee Jae-myung’s leadership reflects South Korea’s strategic push to build sovereign AI infrastructure through partnerships with tech giants like Nvidia.
- **Blackwell chips**
    - Nvidia’s latest generation of AI chips, used in advanced computing and AI applications, including digital twins and autonomous systems.
    - The Blackwell chips are central to the AI infrastructure being deployed in South Korea and are a key product in the company’s global expansion strategy.
- **sovereign AI**
    - A concept referring to AI systems developed and controlled by a nation to ensure national security and technological independence.
    - South Korea’s plan to build sovereign AI infrastructure using Nvidia chips reflects a broader global trend toward national control over AI development.
- **digital twins**
    - Virtual replicas of physical systems, used to simulate and optimize operations across factories and supply chains.
    - Digital twins enabled by Nvidia AI chips will allow factories globally to be interconnected and optimized, marking a significant step in industrial automation.

### Important Dates
  - **2025-10-31**
    - The date of the article reflects a pivotal moment in global AI infrastructure expansion, with Nvidia's major South Korea deals announced during a critical week of geopolitical and technological developments, including US-China trade talks and Nvidia's $5 trillion valuation.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _2025_ to _2025_**
    - The time frame of 2025 marks the current phase of global AI infrastructure rollout, where Nvidia's international expansions—especially into South Korea and potential resumption of sales to China—are shaping the future of AI adoption, digital transformation, and geopolitical technology trade dynamics.

## Big Tech’s A.I. Spending Is Accelerating (Again) - <small>`nytimes`</small>

- [source](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/10/31/technology/ai-spending-accelerating.html)
- _Published: 2025-10-31 05:02:30-04:00_
- **Science & Technology**
- <small>tags: `Artificial Intelligence, Big Tech, Cloud Computing, Data Centers, Tech Spending, Financial Risk, Investor Sentiment, Superintelligence, Market Bubble, AI Regulation, Corporate Strategy`</small>

### Summary

Big Tech companies — primarily Google, Meta, Microsoft, and Amazon — are accelerating their investments in artificial intelligence, with combined spending exceeding $360 billion over the past year. These firms justify the expenditures by citing rising customer demand, particularly for AI data centers, and are expanding cloud infrastructure to meet growing needs. However, financial analysts and central banks like the Federal Reserve and Bank of England have raised concerns about sustainability, warning that overinvestment could lead to a bubble if AI fails to deliver expected returns. While large firms have strong earnings and viable business models, smaller companies lack financial stability and are at greater risk. Meta’s AI strategy is uniquely focused on internal product innovation, such as developing 'superintelligence,' while Microsoft and Google emphasize scalability and customer demand. Despite strong financial performance, investor sentiment is mixed, with Meta’s stock dropping 11% on the day of its earnings announcement, signaling market doubt about the long-term viability of AI spending.

### Key Takeaways
  - Big Tech companies — Google, Meta, Microsoft, and Amazon — are significantly increasing their AI-related capital expenditures, with combined spending exceeding $360 billion over the past 12 months.
  - Despite high spending, AI remains unproven, with uncertain returns and risks of overinvestment if demand fails to materialize or if computing needs are less than projected.
  - The Bank of England and Federal Reserve have expressed caution, noting that such spending could signal financial instability or a bubble, especially if AI fails to deliver expected economic value.
  - While major firms fund AI expansion via strong earnings and existing business models, smaller companies lack financial resilience and may face greater risk in pursuing AI projects.
  - Google, Microsoft, Amazon, and Meta all cited rising customer demand as justification for increased spending, though Microsoft and Google highlighted data center capacity shortages.
  - Meta's AI spending is uniquely tied to internal product development, including its pursuit of 'superintelligence,' which may not generate revenue until advanced AI systems are deployed.
  - Investor confidence is waning — Meta’s stock dropped 11% on the day of the earnings announcement — indicating market skepticism about the sustainability of AI investments.

### Named Entities
- **Google**
    - A major U.S. technology company and a leading provider of cloud computing and artificial intelligence services.
    - Google increased its AI spending by $6 billion, citing rising demand for AI data centers, and now processes 20 times more data through AI products than a year ago.
- **Meta**
    - A major U.S. technology company, parent of Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp, investing heavily in AI infrastructure and 'superintelligence'.
    - Meta raised its AI spending forecast to $70 billion, nearly double its previous year, and is investing in theoretical AI systems that could redefine social media engagement.
- **Microsoft**
    - A major U.S. technology company and cloud computing leader, with a strong AI presence through partnerships like OpenAI.
    - Microsoft increased its AI spending to $35 billion in a single quarter and has $400 billion in future bookings, with an additional $250 billion commitment to buy computing power from OpenAI.
- **Amazon**
    - A major U.S. technology and e-commerce company with a leading role in cloud computing and AI infrastructure.
    - Amazon announced $125 billion in capital expenditures this year, with plans to double its cloud infrastructure capacity by 2027 to meet growing demand.
- **Alphabet**
    - The parent company of Google, responsible for overseeing Google’s AI and data processing initiatives.
    - Alphabet raised its AI spending estimate to $91 billion and reported processing 20 times more data through AI products than a year ago, highlighting scale of AI adoption.
- **OpenAI**
    - An artificial intelligence research company that developed the ChatGPT chatbot and is a key partner for Microsoft and Google.
    - OpenAI is being purchased by Microsoft for $250 billion in computing power, signaling a strategic partnership and deepening tech-AI integration.
- **Federal Reserve**
    - The central banking institution of the United States, responsible for monetary policy and financial stability.
    - The Federal Reserve's chair, Jerome Powell, addressed concerns about AI spending, stating it differs from the dot-com bubble due to strong business models and earnings.
- **Bank of England**
    - The central banking institution of the United Kingdom, which monitors financial stability and data center investment trends.
    - The Bank of England warned that AI-driven data center construction may increasingly rely on debt, raising concerns about financial sustainability if AI underperforms.
- **Sundar Pichai**
    - CEO of Alphabet, and head of Google’s AI development.
    - He stated that Google is processing 20 times more data through AI products than a year ago, showing the scale of AI integration and growth.
- **Amy Hood**
    - Finance Chief at Microsoft.
    - She stated that Microsoft has $400 billion in booked business and emphasized that demand is growing across multiple areas, not just one.
- **Mark Zuckerberg**
    - CEO of Meta, leading AI strategy and development of 'superintelligence'.
    - He emphasized that Meta is investing heavily in superintelligence to be ready for a potential generational shift in AI capabilities.
- **Andy Jassy**
    - CEO of Amazon, leading cloud and infrastructure strategy.
    - He confirmed Amazon’s plan to double cloud infrastructure capacity by 2027, aligning with rising demand and monetization goals.
- **Jerome H. Powell**
    - Chair of the Federal Reserve.
    - He dismissed concerns of a bubble, stating that current AI investments differ from the dot-com era due to strong business models and profitability.
- **The New York Times**
    - A major U.S. media organization involved in a legal dispute over AI copyright infringement.
    - The New York Times sued OpenAI and Microsoft over alleged copyright infringement of news content used in AI systems, highlighting ethical and legal tensions in AI development.

### Important Dates
  - **2025-10-31**
    - The date of publication marks the release of a major report on escalating AI spending by Big Tech, signaling a peak in investment activity and triggering broader financial and policy scrutiny.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _2022_ to _2027_**
    - Amazon committed to doubling its cloud infrastructure capacity from 2022 to 2027, reflecting long-term strategic planning for AI-driven growth and scalability.

## How OpenAI Uses Complex and Circular Deals to Fuel Its Multibillion-Dollar Rise - <small>`nytimes`</small>

- [source](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2025/10/31/technology/openai-fundraising-deals.html)
- _Published: 2025-10-31 00:19:22-04:00_
- **Science & Technology**
- <small>tags: `artificial intelligence, financial innovation, circular deals, tech investment, data centers, market bubble risk, OpenAI, Microsoft, Nvidia, SoftBank, CoreWeave, United Arab Emirates, AI ethics, tech finance`</small>

### Summary

OpenAI is leveraging a network of circular financial deals—such as receiving billions from Microsoft, Nvidia, and SoftBank, then reinvesting those funds to buy computing power, data center space, and stock—driving its AI ambitions. Despite operating at a loss, the company is expanding through partnerships with tech firms like Oracle, CoreWeave, and AMD to build its own data centers. These arrangements, while innovative, raise concerns about financial instability and market bubbles, especially as smaller firms like CoreWeave take on massive debt. The article underscores how financial innovation is as vital as technological progress in AI advancement, and how these interdependent deals could have broad economic implications if AI development stalls.

### Key Takeaways
  - OpenAI's growth is driven not only by AI innovation but by complex, circular financial arrangements that involve reinvesting money back into partner companies.
  - These arrangements include billions of dollars flowing from Microsoft, Nvidia, Oracle, SoftBank, and G42 back into OpenAI to fund computing power and data center development.
  - OpenAI still operates at a loss, relying on future revenue growth from products like ChatGPT to become financially viable.
  - The circular financial model raises concerns about financial bubbles, especially as smaller companies like CoreWeave take on massive debt to build infrastructure.
  - Partners such as Nvidia and AMD have mechanisms to reduce their investments if AI market growth stalls, acting as a form of financial risk management.
  - The article highlights how AI companies are redefining traditional funding models through symbiotic, mutually beneficial but speculative financial partnerships.

### Named Entities
- **Sam Altman**
    - Chief Executive Officer of OpenAI
    - He is the central figure who argues that financial innovation is as critical as technological innovation in driving progress in AI.
- **OpenAI**
    - Artificial intelligence research company
    - The company is the central subject of the article, showcasing how it uses complex financial deals to fund its AI development and data center expansion.
- **Microsoft**
    - Global technology giant
    - Microsoft was OpenAI’s primary investor from 2019 to 2023, contributing over $13 billion and enabling OpenAI’s early AI development through cloud computing services.
- **CoreWeave**
    - AI data center start-up
    - CoreWeave is a key partner in OpenAI’s computing infrastructure, with OpenAI agreeing to pay over $22 billion for computing power and receiving $350 million in stock.
- **SoftBank**
    - Japanese multinational conglomerate
    - SoftBank led a $40 billion investment in OpenAI and is helping fund the construction of data centers in Texas and Ohio.
- **Oracle**
    - Software and cloud computing company
    - Oracle agreed to spend $300 billion building data centers for OpenAI in multiple U.S. states, with OpenAI paying back the same amount over time.
- **G42**
    - Emirati government-linked technology firm
    - G42 is building a $20 billion data center complex for OpenAI in the United Arab Emirates as part of a broader fundraising initiative.
- **Nvidia**
    - Semiconductor and AI chip company
    - Nvidia is investing $100 billion in OpenAI over several years and allowing OpenAI to buy chips, creating a circular financial flow where Nvidia profits from AI growth.
- **AMD**
    - Computer chip manufacturer
    - OpenAI has signed a deal to buy up to 160 million shares of AMD at a penny per share, giving it a 10% stake and providing future capital.
- **Abilene, Texas**
    - Location of OpenAI’s data center
    - The site where OpenAI is building a data center, signaling the company’s physical expansion and investment in U.S. infrastructure.
- **Texas**
    - U.S. state
    - A key location for OpenAI’s data center construction, including sites in Texas and Ohio, as part of its infrastructure expansion strategy.
- **United Arab Emirates**
    - Nation in the Middle East
    - Home to a major data center partnership with G42, reflecting OpenAI’s global expansion strategy and international investment.
- **New York Times**
    - Media organization
    - Sued OpenAI and Microsoft over claims of copyright infringement in AI content, highlighting legal and ethical concerns tied to AI development.

### Important Dates
  - **2019-01-01**
    - The start of OpenAI's long-term partnership with Microsoft, marking the beginning of a major financial relationship that shaped OpenAI's growth trajectory.
  - **2023-12-31**
    - The end point of OpenAI's primary funding period from Microsoft, after which OpenAI began seeking alternative funding sources and expanding its data center partnerships.
  - **2024-10-01**
    - The start of OpenAI’s fundraising round involving the United Arab Emirates, leading to the formation of a major data center project with G42.
  - **2024-11-01**
    - The signing of a major agreement with Oracle to build data centers, signaling OpenAI’s strategic shift toward self-reliance in computing infrastructure.
  - **2025-01-01**
    - The beginning of OpenAI's investment in CoreWeave and other start-ups, reflecting a broader trend of circular financial arrangements in AI development.
  - **2025-10-29**
    - The announcement of Nvidia's $100 billion investment in OpenAI, marking a pivotal moment in the company’s financial model and technological expansion.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _2019_ to _2023_**
    - The period during which Microsoft was OpenAI’s primary investor, shaping the initial financial and technological foundation of the AI company.
  - **From _2024_ to _2025_**
    - The period of rapid expansion in OpenAI's financial model, including new data center partnerships and circular deals with major tech companies.

# Society & Culture

## The ‘6-7’ meme can be annoying. But kids are shouting it for good reason - <small>`cnn`</small>

- [source](https://lite.cnn.com/2025/10/18/us/6-7-meme-slang-explained-cec)
- _Published: 2025-10-31 07:38:00-04:00_
- **Society & Culture**
- <small>tags: `internet meme, Gen Alpha, youth culture, linguistics, school behavior, social shibboleth, viral culture, language evolution, TikTok, internet slang, student behavior, teacher response, post-truth culture, meme longevity`</small>

### Summary

The article explores the rise of the internet meme '6-7' among Gen Alpha youth, which has become a widespread phenomenon in schools and online communities. Originating from a viral song by Skrilla and a gesture popularized by basketball player Taylen Kinney, the phrase has no clear meaning but functions as a social shibboleth, signaling belonging to an in-group. Teachers express frustration with its disruptive nature, while educators and linguists argue that it reflects deeper trends in post-truth communication, youth identity formation, and linguistic evolution. Though the phrase has faced criticism and is expected to eventually fade, its endurance is attributed to adult reactions and the broader cultural significance of meaningless, playful language in youth culture. The article ultimately frames '6-7' not as a sign of brainrot but as a natural, generational expression of how young people create and share culture.

### Key Takeaways
  - The phrase '6-7' has become a widespread internet and school-based meme, with students shouting it in classrooms and online, regardless of context or meaning.
  - The origin of '6-7' is tied to the viral song 'Doot Doot (6 7)' by Skrilla, which references the 10-67 police code, and to a gesture popularized by basketball player Taylen Kinney.
  - The phrase serves as a social shibboleth, signaling belonging to a peer group, and is used to foster community among Gen Alpha youth, even when it has no literal meaning.
  - The phrase has sparked both frustration and fascination among adults, leading to teacher-led responses such as incorporating it into classroom activities or using it ironically to de-escalate the situation.
  - Experts suggest that the popularity of '6-7' reflects broader societal trends such as post-truth communication and semantic bleaching, where language loses meaning through widespread use and reinterpretation.
  - Despite its initial annoyance, the phrase is not considered harmful or indicative of 'brainrot,' and is seen as a natural, generational expression of youth culture.
  - Potential replacements like '41' are emerging as '6-7' begins to lose momentum, indicating the cyclical nature of internet slang.
  - The meme has survived longer than similar internet trends like 'skibidi' due to adult reactions and ongoing cultural engagement.

### Named Entities
- **6-7**
    - A viral internet slang phrase, pronounced 'six-seveeeeen', used by Gen Alpha students in schools and online.
    - The phrase '6-7' is central to the article's exploration of youth culture, internet memes, and language evolution in modern society, serving as a case study in how nonsense phrases gain cultural significance and spread through social media and education systems.
- **Skrilla**
    - A Philadelphia rapper whose song 'Doot Doot (6 7)' is credited as a key catalyst for the rise of the '6-7' meme.
    - The song 'Doot Doot (6 7)' by Skrilla is cited as a likely origin point for the '6-7' phrase, linking the meme to music culture and viral audio trends.
- **Taylen Kinney**
    - A high school basketball phenom who popularized a hand gesture accompanying the phrase '6-7' in a TikTok video.
    - Kinney’s video and TikTok presence helped spread the '6-7' meme into mainstream youth culture, particularly in sports and online communities.
- **LaMelo Ball**
    - Charlotte Hornets point guard who features in sports highlight reels with the '6-7' meme, referencing his height of 6 feet 7 inches.
    - Ball’s inclusion in highlight reels shows how the meme is being integrated into sports culture and used as a humorous reference point, even if he is not directly involved.
- **Gabe Dannenbring**
    - A seventh-grade science teacher in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, who describes the disruptive impact of students shouting '6-7'.
    - Dannenbring provides firsthand teacher perspective on how the meme disrupts classrooms, illustrating its real-world impact on education.
- **Gail Fairhurst**
    - A professor at the University of Cincinnati who studies Gen Alpha communication and youth language trends.
    - Fairhurst offers academic insight into how nonsense phrases like '6-7' serve as social bonding tools and form group identity among youth.
- **Taylor Jones**
    - A linguist and social scientist who analyzes the cultural and linguistic dynamics of internet slang and '6-7'.
    - Jones provides expert analysis on the phenomenon of semantic bleaching and the social function of meaningless phrases in youth culture.
- **Mason 67**
    - An internet-created stereotype of a young, overexcited fan at a basketball game shouting '6-7' with a hand gesture, later becoming a meme character.
    - Mason 67 exemplifies how internet culture turns a simple phrase into a symbolic, anthropomorphic character, contributing to the meme's cultural longevity.
- **Skibidi toilets**
    - A viral internet trend referenced in the article as a comparison to '6-7' in terms of cultural lifespan and absurdity.
    - The comparison shows how internet trends rise and fall, with '6-7' being more durable due to adult reactions and cultural engagement.
- **Rizzes**
    - A slang term used in the article as part of youth language trends, appearing in classroom settings and TikTok culture.
    - Rizzes are presented as part of the broader linguistic landscape of Gen Alpha, showing how multiple slang terms coexist and evolve.
- **Dictionary.com**
    - A website that named '6-7' the word of the year, recognizing its cultural impact.
    - The recognition by Dictionary.com underscores the phrase's widespread cultural significance and mainstream acceptance.
- **Overtime Elite**
    - A basketball development league where Taylen Kinney plays, associated with the spread of the '6-7' gesture.
    - The Overtime Elite team is the context where the initial gesture video was shared, linking the meme to youth sports culture.
- **South Park Elementary**
    - A school mentioned as an example of where students are shouting '6-7' in classrooms.
    - The example shows the meme's reach into public education systems, emphasizing its ubiquity across school environments.
- **Michigan middle school choir teacher**
    - A teacher who incorporated '6-7' into a classroom warm-up song to deflect student protests.
    - The teacher’s strategy demonstrates how educators are adapting to the meme as a social phenomenon, using humor to maintain classroom control.
- **Philip Lindsay**
    - A middle school teacher and comedian who notes the emergence of a potential replacement phrase: '41'.
    - Lindsay provides evidence of the meme’s cyclical nature and predicts its eventual decline in favor of newer slang.
- **Josh Pray**
    - A comedian who has begun using '6-7' in front of his children, attempting to reclaim the phrase from youth culture.
    - Pray's actions reflect adult efforts to engage with or challenge youth-driven slang, showing generational cultural conflict.
- **Know Your Meme**
    - A website that categorizes internet memes, where the 'Mason 67' character is described as an icon of online analog horror.
    - Know Your Meme provides cultural context for the evolution of 'Mason 67' from a simple phrase to a meme character.

### Important Dates
  - **2024-12-01**
    - The viral song 'Doot Doot (6 7)' by Skrilla and the associated gesture by basketball player Taylen Kinney began gaining traction around this time, marking the origin point of the '6-7' meme's rise in popularity.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _2024_ to _2025_**
    - The period from late 2024 to early 2025 marks the peak of '6-7' meme popularity, including widespread use in schools, social media, and sports, with cultural references continuing into 2025.

## Teenage tennis star and 'generational talent' João Fonseca tempering power with patience as he ascends the sport - <small>`cnn`</small>

- [source](https://lite.cnn.com/2025/10/31/sport/tennis-joao-fonseca-profile-intl)
- _Published: 2025-10-31 08:00:00-04:00_
- **Society & Culture**
- <small>tags: `João Fonseca, men's tennis, Brazilian tennis, ATP Tour, young talent, power forehand, Next Gen ATP Finals, Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz, Jannik Sinner, On sports brand, Grand Slam, Brazilian sports culture, rising star, tennis development`</small>

### Summary

João Fonseca, a 19-year-old Brazilian tennis prodigy, has emerged as a generational talent in men’s tennis, known for his powerful forehand that has led to two ATP titles, including a recent win in Basel. His aggressive style, once seen as reckless, evolved after being inspired by Novak Djokovic’s record-breaking Wimbledon final in 2019, leading to a more balanced and patient approach. A former soccer player from Rio de Janeiro, Fonseca turned professional at 17 after reaching the Rio Open quarterfinals and has since won major titles, including at the Next Gen ATP Finals and the Argentina Open. Sponsored by On, a brand linked to Djokovic and other elite players, he is now ranked No. 28 and has set a goal to become a top-32 seed at a Grand Slam. Though he has not yet faced Djokovic, Alcaraz, or Sinner, his rising trajectory and explosive power position him as a potential challenger to the current dominance of the 'Big Three' in men’s tennis.

### Key Takeaways
  - João Fonseca, a 19-year-old Brazilian tennis player, is recognized as a 'generational talent' due to his raw power, especially his forehand, which has led to two ATP Tour titles, including a recent win in Basel.
  - Fonseca's aggressive playing style, initially characterized by reckless power, evolved after being inspired by Novak Djokovic's long Wimbledon final in 2019, leading to a more balanced and patient game.
  - He has won titles at the Next Gen ATP Finals and the Argentina Open, becoming the second-youngest South American ATP title winner in Open Era history.
  - Fonseca is on a rising trajectory, climbing to No. 28 in the ATP rankings after Basel, and has a goal of becoming a top-32 seed at a Grand Slam.
  - He is sponsored by On, a company with ties to Novak Djokovic, and is set to potentially face Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz, and Jannik Sinner in future matches.
  - Fonseca's rise reflects a new generation of tennis players emerging with power and intensity, potentially challenging the current dominance of the 'Big Three' (Djokovic, Alcaraz, Sinner).

### Named Entities
- **João Fonseca**
    - A 19-year-old Brazilian tennis player and a rising star in men's professional tennis.
    - He is the central figure of the article, showcasing a unique blend of power, growth, and potential to challenge the current top players in men’s tennis.
- **Novak Djokovic**
    - Serbian tennis legend and former world No. 1, known for longevity and consistency in the sport.
    - Djokovic inspired João Fonseca's shift in mindset after a 2019 Wimbledon final, and their personal connection (via shared sponsorship and fandom) adds depth to Fonseca’s development story.
- **Carlos Alcaraz**
    - Spanish tennis player, one of the top-ranked and most dominant players in men’s tennis in 2025.
    - Alcaraz is positioned as a key player in the current 'Big Three' and a benchmark against which Fonseca's future success is being measured.
- **Jannik Sinner**
    - Italian tennis player, known for explosive power and consistent performance at Grand Slams.
    - Sinner is also part of the current 'Big Three' and represents the dominant force in men’s tennis that Fonseca aims to join.
- **Iga Świątek**
    - Polish tennis player, a former world No. 1 and one of the most dominant women’s players in history.
    - She is a member of On, the sports brand that sponsors João Fonseca, linking her to Fonseca’s professional journey and brand ecosystem.
- **Ben Shelton**
    - American tennis player, currently ranked among the top players in the world.
    - He is a fellow On-sponsored player, symbolizing the global reach and brand alignment of the On company in men’s and women’s tennis.
- **On**
    - A leading sportswear company with investment in Novak Djokovic and a roster of elite athletes.
    - Fonseca is sponsored by On, which connects him to Djokovic and other elite players, creating a pathway for future matchups and brand influence.
- **Wimbledon**
    - One of the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments, held annually in London.
    - The 2019 Wimbledon final Djokovic won is pivotal in Fonseca’s personal development and shift in playing philosophy.
- **ATP Tour**
    - The Association of Tennis Professionals, which governs men’s professional tennis tours.
    - Fonseca has won titles on the ATP Tour, including at ATP 500 events, highlighting his status in the professional circuit.
- **Next Gen ATP Finals**
    - A tournament for the world’s best players under 20 years of age, designed to showcase emerging talent.
    - Fonseca won this title last year, marking a key achievement in his early career and signaling his potential as a future Grand Slam contender.
- **Brazil**
    - A country where João Fonseca is from and where he has developed his tennis career.
    - Fonseca’s background in Rio de Janeiro and Brazil’s passionate fan culture are essential to understanding his connection to the sport and his fan base.
- **Rio de Janeiro**
    - A city in Brazil, where Fonseca grew up and began his tennis journey.
    - The city’s influence on his early life, soccer background, and fan culture is a foundational element of his identity as a young athlete.
- **University of Virginia**
    - An American university where Fonseca was a student before turning professional.
    - His decision to forgo college eligibility highlights a pivotal turning point in his professional transition.
- **Australian Open**
    - One of the Grand Slam tennis tournaments, held in Australia.
    - Fonseca defeated Andrey Rublev at the Australian Open, a significant win that marked a turning point in his professional reputation.
- **Argentina Open**
    - A tournament in Argentina where Fonseca won a title.
    - His victory at the Argentina Open made him the second-youngest South American ATP title winner in Open Era history.
- **Basel**
    - A city in Switzerland where Fonseca won an ATP 500 title.
    - His win in Basel elevated him to third-youngest ATP 500 winner since 2009 and helped him climb to No. 28 in the rankings.

### Important Dates
  - **2025-10-31**
    - The date of the article's update, indicating the latest information on João Fonseca's rise in men's tennis.
  - **2019-07-01**
    - The year when João Fonseca was profoundly impacted by watching Novak Djokovic win a record-breaking Wimbledon final, leading to a shift in his tennis philosophy and personal growth.
  - **2024-01-01**
    - The date of the Australian Open where João Fonseca defeated Andrey Rublev in a straight-sets match, marking a key milestone in his professional journey.
  - **2024-02-01**
    - The date of the Argentina Open where Fonseca won, becoming the second-youngest South American ATP title winner in the Open Era.
  - **2024-09-01**
    - The date when Fonseca reached the quarterfinals of the Rio Open at age 17, prompting his decision to turn professional.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _2024_ to _2025_**
    - The period during which João Fonseca has been rising through the ATP rankings, winning key titles, and gaining global attention as a promising young talent.
  - **From _2025_ to _2026_**
    - The timeframe in which Fonseca aims to become a top-32 seed at a Grand Slam, reflecting his long-term career goals and development trajectory.

## Lamar Jackson throws four TDs in dominant return from injury to lead Ravens to big win over Dolphins - <small>`cnn`</small>

- [source](https://lite.cnn.com/2025/10/31/sport/football-nfl-week-9-ravens-dolphins-intl)
- _Published: 2025-10-31 05:57:00.000Z_
- **Society & Culture**
- <small>tags: `sports, football, NFL, Lamar Jackson, Baltimore Ravens, Miami Dolphins, return from injury, touchdown passes, team performance, coaching pressure`</small>

### Summary

Lamar Jackson made a strong return from a three-game absence due to a hamstring injury, throwing four touchdown passes in a 28-6 victory over the Miami Dolphins. His performance revitalized the Baltimore Ravens, who improved to 3-5 on the season, while the Dolphins dropped to 2-7 after a game marked by multiple self-inflicted errors. Jackson's outstanding record against Miami, including a 142.9 passer rating, highlights his effectiveness and impact on the game. The loss adds pressure to Dolphins head coach Mike McDaniel, while the Ravens' resurgence offers renewed hope in their playoff aspirations.

### Key Takeaways
  - Lamar Jackson threw four touchdowns in a dominant return from injury, leading the Baltimore Ravens to a 28-6 win over the Miami Dolphins.
  - Jackson's return improved the Ravens' offense significantly, with 338 total yards and 150 rushing yards, including 119 by Derrick Henry.
  - Jackson has an outstanding record against the Dolphins, with 1,405 passing yards, 18 touchdowns, and a 142.9 passer rating in five starts — the highest by any player against a single opponent.
  - The Ravens improved to 3-5 on the season after winning two in a row, showing renewed offensive energy with Jackson back.
  - The Dolphins fell to 2-7, with multiple self-inflicted errors, intensifying pressure on head coach Mike McDaniel.

### Named Entities
- **Lamar Jackson**
    - Professional American football quarterback
    - Jackson is the central figure in the article, leading the Ravens in a dominant performance after a three-game absence due to injury and showcasing his effectiveness against Miami.
- **Baltimore Ravens**
    - Professional American football team
    - The Ravens are the home team in this game and are highlighted for their improved performance with Jackson back, impacting their playoff chances.
- **Miami Dolphins**
    - Professional American football team
    - The Dolphins are the opposing team, and their loss in this game undermines their momentum and raises questions about their coaching and team cohesion.
- **Derrick Henry**
    - Professional American football running back
    - Henry contributed significantly to the Ravens' rushing attack, gaining 119 yards on 19 carries, showing the team's improved ground game.
- **Rashod Bateman**
    - Professional American football wide receiver
    - Bateman caught a touchdown pass from Jackson, highlighting the team’s receiving depth and offensive coordination.
- **Charlie Kolar**
    - Professional American football wide receiver
    - Kolar also scored a touchdown, demonstrating the Ravens' balanced receiving attack.
- **Mark Andrews**
    - Professional American football tight end
    - Andrews caught two touchdowns, showing his importance in Jackson’s offensive scheme and the team’s scoring efficiency.
- **Tahj Washington**
    - Professional American football defensive player
    - Washington fumbled in the first quarter, allowing the Ravens to gain field position and score, a key turning point in the game.
- **Larry Borom**
    - Professional American football defensive player
    - Borom committed a false start on fourth-and-1, ending a promising Dolphins drive and signaling team mismanagement.
- **Riley Patterson**
    - Professional American football kicker
    - Patterson missed a close field goal, contributing to the Dolphins’ defensive and offensive struggles.
- **Malik Washington**
    - Professional American football defensive player
    - Malik Washington fumbled in the fourth quarter, adding to the Dolphins’ self-inflicted errors and game collapse.
- **Mike McDaniel**
    - Head coach of the Miami Dolphins
    - McDaniel is under increasing scrutiny after the Dolphins’ loss, which stems from poor execution and several mistakes, raising questions about his coaching effectiveness.
- **NFL**
    - National Football League
    - The NFL provides context for statistics, records, and historical comparisons, such as Jackson’s record against Miami and team performance trends.
- **CNN**
    - Media organization
    - CNN is the source of the article, providing credibility and media visibility to the story.

### Important Dates
  - **2025-10-31**
    - This is the date of the game and the article's publication, marking Lamar Jackson's return from injury and the Ravens' victory over the Dolphins.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _September 28, 2025_ to _2025-10-31_**
    - Jackson's return to action began on September 28, 2025, marking the start of his comeback from injury, which directly impacted the Ravens' performance and season momentum.

## ‘I feel guilty eating a meal’: Low-income families prepare to lose access to billions in federal aid - <small>`cnn`</small>

- [source](https://lite.cnn.com/2025/10/31/politics/government-shutdown-billions-federal-aid-dries-up)
- _Published: 2025-10-31 05:00:00-04:00_
- **Society & Culture**
- <small>tags: `government shutdown, food insecurity, SNAP, Head Start, LIHEAP, low-income families, social safety net, federal funding, food banks, climate and energy risk, child welfare, economic hardship`</small>

### Summary

As the U.S. government shutdown enters its first month, millions of low-income Americans are facing severe hardship due to the suspension of critical social safety net programs. The USDA has halted SNAP benefits, leaving families like the Kings in Cincinnati to rely on canned food and skip meals, while children lose access to Head Start education and care. In Hillsboro, Ohio, Lauren Lowe must quit her job due to the loss of child care, and in rural Oregon and Minnesota, families are at risk of freezing without heat subsidies from LIHEAP. Food pantries are overwhelmed, with reduced supplies and shortened shelf lives of food. The situation underscores a broader crisis in the U.S. social safety net, where political gridlock is directly impacting vulnerable populations’ access to food, healthcare, and housing. A federal judge in Boston has signaled possible intervention in a legal battle over emergency funds, but for now, millions face immediate financial and emotional strain, with no clear timeline for relief.

### Key Takeaways
  - Low-income families across the U.S. are facing severe financial hardship as federal assistance programs like SNAP, Head Start, and LIHEAP are suspended due to the government shutdown.
  - The suspension of SNAP benefits leads to reduced food quality and quantity, with families relying on canned and boxed foods, and some members skipping meals due to guilt.
  - Head Start programs are closing or being furloughed, threatening children’s access to early education and health care, and forcing some parents to quit their jobs.
  - LIHEAP funding delays increase the risk of home heating failures, especially in rural areas where households rely on propane, wood, or heating oil.
  - Food banks and community organizations are experiencing surges in demand and shortages of essential food items due to the lack of federal support.
  - A federal judge in Boston has indicated potential intervention in a legal battle over USDA’s refusal to disburse emergency funds for SNAP benefits, creating uncertainty about program continuity.
  - The situation reflects a growing crisis in the U.S. social safety net, with multiple programs at risk simultaneously, increasing vulnerability for vulnerable populations.

### Named Entities
- **Annemarie King**
    - Mother and stay-at-home parent
    - She is a representative of low-income families impacted by the loss of SNAP benefits, illustrating the personal hardship of eating less and feeling guilty about consuming meals when children are hungry.
- **Randall King**
    - Father and drywall factory worker
    - He supplements income through extra work, showing how families are trying to compensate for lost federal aid, and how financial strain affects both parents.
- **Cincinnati**
    - City in Ohio
    - Home to the Kings and a key location where SNAP recipients are experiencing reduced access to food and nutritional quality.
- **US Department of Agriculture (USDA)**
    - Federal agency
    - The USDA announced the suspension of SNAP benefits during the shutdown, directly causing the loss of food assistance for millions of low-income families.
- **Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)**
    - Federal food assistance program
    - The program is suspended during the shutdown, directly affecting over 4.4 million Americans who rely on it to afford food.
- **Head Start**
    - Early childhood education program
    - Programs are being closed or furloughed, threatening children's development and forcing parents to quit jobs or face financial hardship.
- **National Head Start Association**
    - Organization representing Head Start programs
    - It reported that over 65,000 children and families could lose access to Head Start services in November.
- **Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP)**
    - Federal program for heating assistance
    - It is on hold during the shutdown, putting vulnerable families—especially in rural areas—at risk of unsafe living conditions due to lack of heat.
- **Hillsboro, Ohio**
    - City in Ohio
    - Home to Lauren Lowe, whose family will lose Head Start access, forcing her to quit her job and face increased financial pressure.
- **Lauren Lowe**
    - Mother and restaurant server
    - She represents a parent forced to quit work due to loss of child care, increasing household financial strain and reducing access to food and basic needs.
- **Carter**
    - Child of Lauren Lowe
    - He is emotionally affected by the closure of Head Start, showing how children are directly impacted by the suspension of social services.
- **Julia Wise**
    - Executive director of Highland County Community Action Organization
    - She leads the Hillsboro Head Start program and provides insight into operational challenges and staff furloughs due to funding cuts.
- **Kasey Lawson**
    - Head Start director for Mid-America Regional Council
    - She reports that 17 Head Start programs in the Kansas City area chose to stay open at financial risk, showing uncertainty in program sustainability.
- **Ronda Beck**
    - Resident of Lakeville, Minnesota
    - She illustrates the impact of LIHEAP suspension and SNAP loss, facing difficulty covering electric bills and preparing for food insecurity.
- **Willissa Bullock**
    - Resident of Landover, Maryland
    - She highlights the strain on food pantries due to reduced supply and increased demand from furloughed federal workers and unemployed individuals.
- **No Limits Outreach Ministries**
    - Food pantry in Landover, Maryland
    - It is experiencing supply shortages and reduced food availability due to canceled pandemic-era relief programs and declining shipments.
- **Community Action Program of East Central Oregon**
    - Nonprofit serving rural Oregon residents
    - It manages LIHEAP-related services and reports that over $200,000 in grant payments are on hold, threatening residents' safety during winter.
- **Code for America**
    - Organization improving access to safety net programs
    - It estimates that 4.4 million people will lose SNAP benefits on November 1, helping track the scale of the crisis.
- **Capitol Hill**
    - Political district in Washington D.C.
    - Annemarie King refers to the political stalemate on Capitol Hill as a cause of the shutdown, showing how political gridlock affects everyday people’s lives.
- **Covid-19-era relief programs**
    - Previously funded programs
    - Their cancellation has reduced supply to food pantries, compounding the crisis in food availability.
- **Federal government shutdown**
    - Event
    - The central cause of the suspension of multiple federal safety net programs, directly impacting low-income families nationwide.

### Important Dates

## Salem’s witches were pardoned, but Britain’s weren’t. There’s now a movement to change that - <small>`cnn`</small>

- [source](https://lite.cnn.com/2025/10/31/uk/salem-britain-witches-pardon-campaign-scli-intl)
- _Published: 2025-10-31 12:01:00Z_
- **Society & Culture**
- <small>tags: `witchcraft trials, historical injustice, women's rights, public executions, Maidstone, Penenden Heath, Witchcraft Act of 1562, pardon campaign, Scotland apology, Turing pardon, UK history`</small>

### Summary

While Salem witches in colonial America were pardoned, women executed in England under the Witchcraft Act of 1562—such as the six accused in a 1652 trial in Maidstone, Kent—are still legally convicted. The trial, marked by public spectacle, hysteria, and the execution of vulnerable women, has prompted Maidstone Borough Council, led by councillors Claire Kehily and Tony Harwood and leader Stuart Jeffery, to call for a formal pardon. This campaign follows precedents like the Turing pardon and Scotland’s 2022 apology, aiming to correct historical injustices, recognize gender-based scapegoating, and ensure that past atrocities are not forgotten. The campaign highlights the enduring relevance of these events as a warning against institutionalized violence and prejudice.

### Key Takeaways
  - In England, more than 500 women were tried for witchcraft between 1560 and 1700, with 112 executed, in stark contrast to the pardoning of Salem witches in colonial America.
  - The 1652 trial in Maidstone, Kent, involved six women accused of bewitching a newborn, her mother, and a young child, drawing large crowds and a public spectacle.
  - Three of the accused failed a crude pin test and two confessed to being impregnated by the devil; all six were convicted and executed at Penenden Heath.
  - Public executions were events of mass participation, with thousands attending, and the execution site was moved due to public disturbance and crime waves.
  - Human remains from executions were often buried or discarded, with no formal burial or memorialization until recently.
  - A small stone plaque now commemorates the six women executed at Penenden Heath, along with others executed at the site.
  - Maidstone Borough Council, led by Stuart Jeffery and supported by councillor Claire Kehily and Tony Harwood, is campaigning for a formal pardon under the Witchcraft Act of 1562.
  - This campaign follows precedents such as the 2013 Turing pardon for gay men convicted under anti-homosexuality laws and Scotland’s 2022 apology to witchcraft victims.
  - The campaign highlights witchcraft trials as early forms of gender-based violence and scapegoating, especially against poor and vulnerable women and girls.

### Named Entities
- **Salem**
    - A historical location in colonial America where women were accused and pardoned in the 1692 witch trials.
    - Salem serves as a contrast to the unresolved convictions in Britain, showing how colonial America formally pardoned its witch trials while Britain still maintains legal convictions.
- **Maidstone**
    - A town in Kent, England, where a major witch trial occurred in 1652 involving six women accused of witchcraft.
    - The town is central to the article’s narrative, as it is the site of one of the most publicized and notorious witch trials in England and the focus of a current campaign for pardon.
- **Penenden Heath**
    - A park in southeast England where the six women from the 1652 Maidstone trial were executed.
    - It is the execution site, where public spectacles of execution occurred, and where bodies were discarded, now marked only by a small commemorative plaque.
- **Witchcraft Act of 1562**
    - A UK law that criminalized witchcraft and enabled the prosecution of hundreds of women in England between 1560 and 1700.
    - The law is the legal foundation for the witch trials and remains in effect in terms of standing convictions, prompting calls for a pardon.
- **Claire Kehily**
    - A councillor for Maidstone Borough Council who describes the historical trials and supports the campaign for pardons.
    - She is a key local official advocating for historical justice and highlighting witchcraft trials as early gender-based violence against vulnerable women.
- **Tony Harwood**
    - A councillor for Maidstone Borough Council who speaks about the public nature and terror of the executions.
    - He provides firsthand insight into the public spectacle of executions and the societal terror they caused, emphasizing the injustice of the trials.
- **Stuart Jeffery**
    - Leader of Maidstone Borough Council who has written to the UK Home Secretary urging a pardon for those executed under the Witchcraft Act.
    - He is the primary political figure driving the campaign for a formal pardon, linking it to broader principles of justice and historical accountability.
- **Shabana Mahmood**
    - The UK Home Secretary who is being contacted by Maidstone Council to respond to their pardon request.
    - She is the governmental official who will determine whether a pardon is granted, making her a key point of contact in the policy shift.
- **Scotland**
    - A country in the UK where a formal apology was issued in 2022 to those executed under witchcraft laws.
    - Scotland’s 2022 apology provides precedent for similar pardons and official recognition of historical injustice in witchcraft trials.
- **Alan Turing**
    - A British codebreaker convicted under laws criminalizing homosexuality, posthumously pardoned by Queen Elizabeth II in 2013.
    - The Turing pardon serves as a precedent for pardoning victims of discriminatory laws, such as those used in witchcraft trials.
- **Turing Law**
    - A UK government policy in 2017 that extended pardons to thousands of gay and bisexual men convicted under anti-homosexuality laws.
    - It demonstrates how the UK government has taken steps to correct historical injustices through legislation, supporting the argument for a similar pardon for witchcraft victims.
- **UK Parliament**
    - The legislative body that estimated over 500 women were tried for witchcraft in southeast England between 1560 and 1700.
    - It provides authoritative historical data on the scale of witchcraft prosecutions, reinforcing the significance of the campaign for justice.
- **First Minister Nicola Sturgeon**
    - A Scottish political leader who issued a formal apology in 2022 to those executed under witchcraft laws.
    - Her actions serve as a precedent for official recognition and apology of historical injustices related to witchcraft trials.

### Important Dates
  - **1652-07-30**
    - The date of the Maidstone witch trial in which six women were accused and convicted of witchcraft, marking a peak in public hysteria and judicial execution in southeast England.
  - **1560-12-31**
    - The start of the period during which over 500 women in southeast England were tried for witchcraft, with the Witchcraft Act of 1562 being the legal framework that enabled these trials.
  - **1700-12-31**
    - The end of the period during which witchcraft trials were active in England, signaling the decline of the witchcraft hysteria and the eventual repeal of witchcraft laws.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _1560_ to _1700_**
    - The period from 1560 to 1700 when over 500 women were tried for witchcraft in southeast England, including the notorious Maidstone trial in 1652.

## Latter-day Saints Are Having Fewer Children, Church Leaders Take Note - <small>`npr`</small>

- [source](https://text.npr.org/nx-s1-5535654)
- _Published: 2025-10-31 05:00:00-04:00_
- **Society & Culture**
- <small>tags: `birth rates, Latter-day Saints, family size, demographic shift, spiritual values, economic pressures, Mormon community, postpartum depression, religious family values, community support`</small>

### Summary

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is experiencing a significant decline in birth rates, with the proportion of women aged 18–45 having at least one child dropping from 70% in 2008 to 59% in 2022. This trend, which mirrors broader U.S. demographic shifts, is being acknowledged by church leadership, including newly appointed prophet Dallin H. Oaks, who stresses the spiritual importance of family despite declining numbers. Personal narratives from members like the Allens and Gabbotts reveal that rising housing costs, childcare expenses, postpartum depression, and mental health struggles are key factors influencing family decisions. Community leaders and scholars note that while traditional expectations of large families are waning, the faith continues to emphasize eternal family bonds. The article highlights a broader cultural shift—individuals are redefining family size through personal, financial, and spiritual considerations, even as they remain committed to core religious beliefs about marriage and reproduction.

### Key Takeaways
  - Latter-day Saints are having fewer children, with a notable decline from 70% to 59% of women aged 18–45 having at least one child at home between 2008 and 2022.
  - This trend mirrors broader U.S. demographic shifts, indicating that economic pressures like high housing costs and childcare expenses are influencing family planning decisions.
  - Church leaders, including Dallin H. Oaks, emphasize the spiritual importance of family and eternal relationships, even as birth rates decline.
  - Members express both personal and theological reflections on having fewer children, balancing faith with real-world challenges such as affordability and mental health.
  - There is growing cultural shift within the community: pressure to have many children is declining, and individuals are prioritizing personal well-being and spiritual connection over traditional family size expectations.

### Named Entities
- **The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints**
    - A major religious group, often referred to as 'Mormons', with over 17.5 million members globally.
    - The article centers on the declining birth rates within this church, which historically had high fertility rates and is now adapting to a smaller family trend.
- **Dallin H. Oaks**
    - The newly appointed prophet and president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
    - He addressed declining birth rates during the General Conference, emphasizing the spiritual value of marriage and family in Latter-day Saint theology.
- **Bishop Steve Eror**
    - A bishop who oversees a congregation in Salt Lake City, where the church headquarters is located.
    - He personally observes the decline in youth and children in his congregation, leading to adaptations like partnering with another congregation to maintain youth programs.
- **Stephen Cranney**
    - A demographer from the Catholic University of America who analyzed Latter-day Saint family statistics.
    - He provided data showing a decline in childbearing among Latter-day Saint women from 70% in 2008 to 59% in 2022, supporting the trend analysis.
- **Ryan and Missy Allen**
    - A married couple in Utah who have two children and chose not to have more due to financial strain.
    - They represent individual families navigating economic challenges and personal decisions about family size in the context of Latter-day Saint beliefs and values.
- **Gregory and Anna Gabbott**
    - A married couple in Bountiful, Utah, who have two daughters and chose to stop having more children due to postpartum depression, sleep issues, and financial pressures.
    - They illustrate how personal health, emotional challenges, and societal pressures influence family decisions within the faith community.
- **Spencer James**
    - A family life professor at Brigham Young University and a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
    - He provides a scholarly perspective on how lower birth rates may reflect a lack of community support and shifting cultural norms among Latter-day Saints.

### Important Dates
  - **2008-01-01**
    - In 2008, 70% of Latter-day Saint women aged 18–45 had at least one child at home, indicating a peak in family size before a noticeable decline.
  - **2022-01-01**
    - By 2022, that rate had dropped to 59%, showing a significant decline in childbearing among Latter-day Saints, mirroring broader U.S. trends.
  - **2025-10-31**
    - The article was published on October 31, 2025, during the October General Conference, when church leadership addressed declining birth rates.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _2008_ to _2022_**
    - The period from 2008 to 2022 reflects a significant decline in Latter-day Saint childbearing, from 70% to 59% of women aged 18–45 having children at home.
